reviewText:
This little gem caught me off guard.

Remember what it means to be a human in this interactive biography of a dead astronaut found in deep space by future intelligences who have no concept of humankind."

It's a short game involving exploring and re-piecing memories together of an astronauts life. There's nothing more to the story than that. Where the game thrives is with it's music and game-play. In this title you use both sticks of a controller to handle one of two lasers
date: and you have to manually go through nodes / pieces of memory molecules to collect them.\n\nIt's like Rez and guitar hero had a baby and instead of wanting to shoot things
recommended: it just wanted to make music. I was able to play this and numerous people walked by and stopped to just see what was going on
hoursPlayed: my son even stopped playing with his cars to stare in awe at all the shiny things going on on the screen and numerous times I found myself bobbing along with the music moving up and down and shifting in my seat to match the lasers.\n\nAs I mentioned

reviewText:
This game feels like a spiritual successor to Rez on the PS2 which was one of my favorites. Fairly short, but has great replay value. The environments are both bizarre and beautiful. The story is intriguing and told in an interesting manner, and while being simlpe it really drew me in.

As others have said this game requires a controller to play. Specifically an XInput compatible controller.

5/5

reviewText:
A future intelligence with no concept of what a human being is finds a dead astronaut and proceeds to reconstruct his memories to try and understand what he is and what happened: this translates into a game where you control two beams of light and collect memories accompanied by high tempo music and beautiful sights.
Laserlife is part rhythm game part trippy experience and, while brief, its fun gameplay, great music and dreamlike imagery make it an hidden gem.

PROS:

-good graphics, the various images appearing during levels are nicely done and in sync with the music

-great soundtrack, good sound design

-the gameplay is simple but quite fun and slowly ramps up in speed and difficulty

-tight and responsive controls

-different difficulty levels make the game as relaxing or as challenging as you want

-slowly uncovering memories is nice, while there's no real story discovering the astronaut's life and what happened on his last trip was intriguing

-leaderboards for each game level and difficulty setting for those so inclined

CONS:

-a few sections get a bit too crowded on the background, making memory pieces hard to see

-a slight framerate drop at the end of some levels ( no impact on gameplay, but was a bit annoying)

-short, it'll take you 1,5/2 hours to finish and, unless you want to go for an high score on certain levels, there's no replay value

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=547429090

I really liked Laserlife, the gameplay is fun and keeps you on your toes, the levels sport nice and trippy graphics, the soundtrack alternates between high tempo and slower tracks to mix things up a bit and the various memories were interesting enough to keep going for more.

It's a bit of a shame that it's so short, the 12 levels go by quickly (in fact the devs recommend playing through the game in one sitting) and once you're done there's not much else to do, they'd also have done a bit more with the story rather than just giving us bits and pieces of memories.

All things considered if you're a fan of the genre or just want something different Laserlife is an easy recommendation, just avoid getting it for full price since I feel it's too much for the amount of gameplay you get: thankfully it goes as low as 5$ when on sale.

reviewText: This game tries to sell you on a premise right out of the gate. I think it does, the stages feel pretty nice, and getting the scores are part of the challenge. I like what i've played, however brief. It is a solid rhythm game that keeps you on the toes as it dances about. I don't know about the length, but the music, the graphics, and the whole approach just nabs you and doesnt let go. If its as short as other reviews say, I can see getting it on sale. But I'd get dlc for this in a heartbeat. Easily worth 5-10 bucks for what you are getting I would think, especially going back for challenges.\n\nSo, i hope that this review gives you a glimpse from a music fan. (And to give my hands a break on the constant movement that the stages demand.)

reviewText: If you're a fan of their previous game series, Bit Trip, you will love the two hours it will take you to complete all of the levels. Fantastic music and visuals, supported by it's mechanics really make you feel part of the music. However, it is extremely short, and this really is what makes it not worth its price at all. It should be a quarter of the price it is demanding. There is no reason for having a score in this, it doesn't give you anything extra when you do nail a perfect level. As soon as you start getting a feel for its mechanics..it ends, that's it, no more content, just re-do the levels if you wish.\nI'll be asking for a refund, there are plenty of other games for the same price that are just as great but with quadruple the content. I really suggest waiting for a sale of atleast 60% off.

reviewText:
I made a video review for this game.

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WelRLqMjkhc

Transcription:

Ambidextrous? Choice Provisions new game LaserLife, is for you. It’s a rhythm based twin-stick game, I know it’s been done before but this is my first experience with it, and I have to say, I was charmed by this game.

It took me about 10 seconds of gameplay for my brain to kind of click and get into multi-task mode. Maybe I’m particularly quick I don’t know, but I feel like I was almost immediately in the zone with this game. The movement is snappy which is a must for a game like this, and another must is that it feels satisfying and natural to play which it does. The way I’m describing makes it sound relaxing, but don’t let me fool you because the game is pretty fast paced right from the start, and it only gets more intense. Most people will be comfortable with the first few levels, but it really doesn’t take long to ramp up the difficulty.

Though i will say that if you are looking for, begin quote “challenge” end quote, this might not be the place to look for it or it might not be the kind of challenge you're looking for. That really isn’t to say that the levels are too easy, but more like I’m not even sure you can lose a level. Hopefully right now I’m not coming off as a massive ♥♥♥♥ because I got lucky and didn’t have to replay levels, but to me it seemed like you can really mess up the levels and still unlock the next one. There certainly is challenge if you're going for perfect scores, but not really in terms of progression.

That’s a nitpick really though because the developers even say that it is designed to be played in one sitting as an experience, and I can confirm after completing it in about an hour that this is definitely the way it is meant to be played. And this is probably the biggest criticism I have, is that it isn’t a whole lot of content for the $15 asking price. While I was playing the game for some reason I was thinking it was $5 and it would have been a steal at that price, but I feel like $15 is a little too steep.

That said the music is pretty phenomenal, though they do repeat the tracks sometimes they do it in a clever way. Each stage has sub-stages within them that have different music. It’s hard to really explain unless you play it but I think that it works pretty well.

Something that really impressed me was the effort put into the background. Since you’re playing through memories in the game there’s opportunity to put the player in different environments with different styles of music. The music did remain, maybe a little disappointingly, quite consistent in terms of style, but the developers did take full advantage of the premise when it came to backgrounds. There’s 12 levels in total, and each level has a unique section to it with a cool animated background. I’m just particularly impressed because for a game like this it’s pretty easy to throw the backgrounds in, and not really have a story or premise, but this game has a pretty compelling one, and by the end I felt a little emotional. I think it would have been more effective though if they had made this game as a tribute to a real life person; because that’s what the story feels like, but the main character is a nameless astronaut which is kinda disappointing.

I should also mention that the gameplay is shaken up slightly with the sub stages within the stages, and a couple mechanics throughout.

If the game really interests you, go for it. I really enjoyed my time with this game. That said, if you're someone who wants time out of the money they spend, feels like $15 isn’t worth an hour or hour and a half of entertainment, or is just kinda sorta interested, then maybe wait for a sale. But, when on it goes on sale, absolutely pick it up because it’s a pretty awesome game.

Thanks for watching, if you feel that I deserve it and I’ve helped you with your purchasing decision, consider leaving a like. If you don’t think I deserve it, feel free to leave a dislike but if you do, try to leave me some feedback; let me know why you didn’t like the review. And if you wanna keep up with my reviews; I try to review new games pretty regularly, I would appreciate a subscription.

reviewText:
Important! Laserlife cannot be played without a controller. Its not that it has bad keyboard compatibility, it has none.
If you don't have a controller, Laserlife is 'Intel RealSense' compatible. See website for more details:http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/architecture-and-technology/realsense-overview.html

Like any game on Steam, Laserlife has its ups and downs. Luckily the ups far outnumber the downs.
Laserlife has a story at its heart, as in the description, it is the story of a dead astronaut from childhood to death. And its a good one.
Telling a story without any words* is always a challenge, relying upon visuals**, sound and imagination. And let me tell you, Laserlife has all of the above. It delivers a beautifully crafted piece of storytelling with brilliant creativity that really does make you stop and think. Take it from me, I'm no sentimentalist.

There are three Acts"; Childhood
date: Adulthood and Death.\nEach Act has 4 levels
recommended: each leading to a different milestone in memory.\nEach level in the game is made up of 4 phases and is set up as a kind of twin-stick runner
hoursPlayed: utilising 2 lasers.\nThe 'Collection' phase. Using the lasers
voteText: collect memory fragments. Numbers increase and decrease through levels
helpfulPercent: typically 150-200 fragments per run.\nThe 'Harmonising' phase. This time
votesHelpful: the lasers must simply impact the fragments. Unlike the previous phase
votesTotal: lasers cannot move across the middle of the screen\nThe 'Warp' stage. This is somewhat easier than the last 2 phases but frustrating if it is done incorrectly. It is a tunnel runner
votesFunny: making sure the lasers do not hit the oncoming obstacles. Hitting once will lose whatever chain was amassed the previous phase
commentsCount: repeated hits will result in restarting the 'Harmonising' phase.\nThe 'Power' phase. This phase lasts only a few seconds and has no lasers. Simply rotate the joysticks at speed.\nThe environment of the 'Collection' phase is the same over the Act
column16: therefore there are only 3 'Collection' environments in the game.\nThey are a kind of pseudo-psychadelic representation of that certain stage in life. They are meant to stimulate thought
column17: emotion and - most importantly - your imagination.\n\nThe environment of the 'Harmonising' phase is where the story really comes into play. Using the same kind of style as the previous phase
column19: they tell a certain aspect of the story - a significant part in the astronauts' life.\n\nThe 'Warp' phase has a tunnel environment
column20: nothing other than that. Various obstacles block your path
column21:
easily navigable...mostly.

The 'Power' phase revolves around the captured astronaut as the memory is vigorously extracted.

The music is a fine example of techno done right and complements the gameplay fantastically. It is also really quite helpful with timing.

Overall this is a triumph of modern day storytelling
column22: employing original and highly creative means.\n\nHowever
column23: I did mention downsides.\nThe primary downside is that this game is far too short! I completed it within 2 hours and that includes a few repeats. The only way to make it longer is to aim for perfect scores.\nI implore the devs to add some more content
column25: anything!\n\nThis leads me onto the second point which is that the price tag is
column28: you can see where the money has gone and I
column30: can understand that but charging £11.00 (~$16.00) for just a few hours isn't something many can commend.\nAs such
column31: I can't recommend full price for this game
column32:
brilliant as it is - buy it on sale.

*The only words in the entire game come from random excerpts of real dialogue between NASA astronauts and ground control (added for effect) and the poignant explanation at the end of a level.

**The visuals are truly great

reviewText:
This game is exactly as cool as its premise. You are assembling a dead astronaut's memories in a very alien way through a really neat rhythm game.

Pros:
+Visually impressive and well optimized (except right after level completion, occasionally)
+Really fun and unique gameplay. I haven't played a rhythm game like this before (although I have seen comparisons made). If you could somehow put in your own music, this would replace Audiosurf 2 for me.
+Futuristic and alien music. The music is easy to feel
date:
which is obviously important in a rhythm game.
+Again, the premise and concept are just really cool. You'll be fascinated by the story and visuals by the time the menu screen shows up.

Neutral:
=Some of the fragments that you have to push an analog stick just partially to get are nearly impossible with the first person moving forward setup. You'll see what I mean in later levels.
=You'll hear the same songs over several times in the first and third stages of each memory in a group.
=The game is <2.5 hours. Concise, yes. But you'll probably want more!

Cons:
-You have no idea what the camera/your trajectory will do, causing you to miss some fragments.
-Your lasers move much too slowly for some of the fragments in later levels. I know it's possible, but it just feels unfair and clunky.

As you can see, my issues are mostly just minor gameplay complaints that can be overcome by getting good. If you have doubts about the game, I recommend just tossing it on your wishlist and waiting for a sale, as the game is short.

reviewText:
Difficult to recommend but an interesting game overall.I'm really conflicted whether to put thumbs up or thumbs down.

The gameplay is quite weak and the controls are difficult, when finally you get the hang of it the game is over. I would have prefered some sort of analog input instead of digital input of controller analog sticks. In short the controlls definitely affected my gemplay negatively. I've started out with xbox 360 controller which was terrible, switched to wii u pro controller and it definitely made the controlls more bearable.

The presentation is superb though that might be because I'm a huge sucker for ambient kind of entertainment. The music is great as well as are the visuals, animation. The store is pretty barebones but I think that's actually a plus in this case.

I've finished the whole game in 80 minutes as a casual run, meaning I did every level once with no resets.
Would I recommend it for 15€ ? No.
For 5€? Probably, but only if the trailer caught your eye because the whole game is pretty much extended trailer with uncomfy gameplay tacked on.
At the end of the day the game just feels nice if you are into ambient elektronika.
